articles.headline: Coronavirus Shut Down the ‘Experience Economy.’ Can It Come Back?
articles.snippet: Large-scale gatherings are on hold for the foreseeable future. That is taking a toll on the live events industry and society at large.
articles.abstract: Large-scale gatherings are on hold for the foreseeable future. That is taking a toll on the live events industry and society at large.
articles.lead_paragraph: A quandary is lurking at the heart of the efforts to revive the economy.

articles.headline: In China’s Crisis, Xi Sees a Crucible to Strengthen His Rule
articles.snippet: China’s leader is using the country’s success — and the criticism against it — to urge the party and the people to weather tough days ahead.
articles.abstract: China’s leader is using the country’s success — and the criticism against it — to urge the party and the people to weather tough days ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before an adulatory crowd of university professors and students, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, offered a strikingly bold message about the global coronavirus pandemic. Summoning images of sacrifice from Communist Party lore, he told them that the calamity was ripe with possibility for China.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: All 50 States Are Now Reopening. But at What Cost?
articles.snippet: Governors face intensifying pressure to reopen their economies, but experts warn it could mean thousands of new deaths.
articles.abstract: Governors face intensifying pressure to reopen their economies, but experts warn it could mean thousands of new deaths.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Connecticut, flags that had been lowered during the somber peak of the coronavirus pandemic were raised to full-staff on Wednesday to signal a return to business.
articles.byline: By Sarah Mervosh and Amy Harmon

articles.headline: As Virus Lingers in Michigan, a New Crisis Arrives: Flooding
articles.snippet: Thousands of residents of Midland, Mich., fled their homes as waters rose, trying to keep at a safe social distance even in shelters.
articles.abstract: Thousands of residents of Midland, Mich., fled their homes as waters rose, trying to keep at a safe social distance even in shelters.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIDLAND, Mich. — Along Main Street in the central Michigan city of Midland, residents crowded the sidewalk on Wednesday, watching the rising waters of the Tittabawassee River in stunned despair. Floodwaters lapped less than a block away, and a row of businesses, their electricity cut off, stood dark and quiet.
articles.byline: By Kathleen Gray and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: Lockdown Delays Cost at Least 36,000 Lives, Data Show
articles.snippet: Even small differences in timing would have prevented the worst exponential growth, which by April had subsumed New York City, New Orleans and other major cities, researchers found.
articles.abstract: Even small differences in timing would have prevented the worst exponential growth, which by April had subsumed New York City, New Orleans and other major cities, researchers found.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the United States had begun imposing social distancing measures one week earlier than it did in March, about 36,000 fewer people would have died in the coronavirus outbreak, according to new estimates from Columbia University disease modelers.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Campbell Robertson

articles.headline: Pandemic-Baking Britain Has an ‘Obscene’ Need for Flour
articles.snippet: The Wessex Mill in Oxfordshire, a family business started 125 years ago, is among the British mills striving to meet a surge in demand.
articles.abstract: The Wessex Mill in Oxfordshire, a family business started 125 years ago, is among the British mills striving to meet a surge in demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: A week before Britain came to a standstill in mid-March, the Wessex Mill found itself fielding nearly 600 calls a day requesting one of the country’s hottest commodities: flour.

articles.headline: China’s ‘Crude Oil Treasure’ Promised Riches. Now Investors Owe the Bank.
articles.snippet: The police are seeking to silence those who bought a Bank of China investment that backfired, highlighting the plight of small investors in the country.
articles.abstract: The police are seeking to silence those who bought a Bank of China investment that backfired, highlighting the plight of small investors in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: The pitches, from one of China’s biggest and most established banks, made the investment seem like a sure bet.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li

articles.headline: For Spy Agencies, Briefing Trump Is a Test of Holding His Attention
articles.snippet: President Trump’s intelligence briefings have gotten renewed attention since he blamed them for failing to sound the alarm early on about the coronavirus.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s intelligence briefings have gotten renewed attention since he blamed them for failing to sound the alarm early on about the coronavirus.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has blamed many others for his administration’s flawed response to the coronavirus: China, governors, the Obama administration, the World Health Organization. In recent weeks, he has also faulted the information he received from an obscure analyst who delivers his intelligence briefings.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Bethenny Frankel’s Dark Journey to Find Medical Masks
articles.snippet: New York officials tapped the reality television star to find masks for medical workers. She found a global bazaar of ex-cons and exaggerations.
articles.abstract: New York officials tapped the reality television star to find masks for medical workers. She found a global bazaar of ex-cons and exaggerations.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was late March, with the coronavirus starting to peak in New York and hospitals already running short on supplies, when Bethenny Frankel, the entrepreneur and reality television star, received an email from a publicist offering her access to 500 million medical masks, or about enough to fill 25 Madison Square Gardens.

articles.headline: The Striking Racial Divide in How Covid-19 Has Hit Nursing Homes
articles.snippet: Homes with a significant number of black and Latino residents have been twice as likely to be hit by the coronavirus as those where the population is overwhelmingly white.
articles.abstract: Homes with a significant number of black and Latino residents have been twice as likely to be hit by the coronavirus as those where the population is overwhelmingly white.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the suburbs of Baltimore, workers at one nursing home said they were given rain ponchos to protect from infection. Twenty-seven employees at the facility, where most residents are African-American, tested positive for the coronavirus.

articles.headline: Many Jobs May Vanish Forever as Layoffs Mount
articles.snippet: With over 38 million U.S. unemployment claims in nine weeks, one economist says the situation is “grimmer than we thought.”
articles.abstract: With over 38 million U.S. unemployment claims in nine weeks, one economist says the situation is “grimmer than we thought.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as states begin to reopen for business, a further 2.4 million workers joined the nation’s unemployment rolls last week, and there is growing concern among economists that many of the lost jobs are gone for good.

articles.headline: China Moves to Tighten Its Control of Hong Kong
articles.snippet: New security laws would allow Beijing to take aim at the protests that have roiled the semiautonomous city and posed a direct challenge to the Communist Party and its leader, Xi Jinping.
articles.abstract: New security laws would allow Beijing to take aim at the protests that have roiled the semiautonomous city and posed a direct challenge to the Communist Party and its leader, Xi Jinping.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China signaled on Thursday it would move forward with laws that would take aim at antigovernment protests and other dissent in Hong Kong. It is the clearest message yet that the Communist Party is moving to undermine the civil liberties the semiautonomous territory has known since the 1997 British handoff.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher, Austin Ramzy and Tiffany May
